For instance, one could define velocity = duration / 100. + onset * 0.01 or cents = cents + 200, or onset = [cents - 6000] / 100 + 2000 * [voice - 1]. The equation syntax extends in a sense the relative modification syntax; however it is applied to the globality of the selection, and one cannot apply different equations to different notes inside the chord.

method.name: voice
method.digest: Modify the voice of selected items
method.description:
Syntax: voice <int/llll/anything: voice_number>
Examples:
• voice 2 → put selected notes in second voice
• voice = 2 → exactly the same
• voice = voice + 1 → shift voices
• voice = "random[1, 4]" → assign voice randomly between 1 and 3
• voice = [3 - voice]*[voice <= 2] + voice * [voice > 2] → swap first two voices
The word voice, followed by a number, sets the new voice number for all the selected notes or chords. Any of the numbers in the voice syntax can be replaced by an llll containing a relative modification of the existing voice. If a single number is inserted, this can be replaced by a generic equation.
All parameters, except for bach.score's timepoints, also support a relative modification syntax, which modifies the existing values instead Relative modifications of a parameter are handled via lllls of the type [value function], where the function is one of the following symbols: "plus", "minus", "times", "div". Such modification applies the corresponding function to the current value of the parameter and the inserted value. For instance, [100 minus] removes 100 to the current value of the parameter, while [2. times] multiplies it by two.
All separate parameters, except for measureinfo, ties and slots, can also be modified via a generic equation. In order to do so, the message symbol must be followed by an = sign (with spaces before and after it), and then by the desired equation. The standard symbolic variables are available.
Symbolic variables are variables that can be used in the conditional selection or parameter modification processes. These are: onset (in ms), duration (in ms), velocity, cents (pitch in MIDIcents), pitch (diatonic pitch), tail (position of the note end, in ms), voice (voice number), part (part number), voiceensemble (voiceensemble number). For bach.score you can also use: symduration (symbolic rational duration), symonset (symbolic rational onset inside the measure), symtail (sum of the two previous), measure (the measure number), tie (which is 1 if a tie starts, 2 if a tie ends and 3 if a tie both starts and ends, 0 otherwise) and grace (1 for grace chords, 0 otherwise).
In addition, you also have the index symbol, corresponding to the index of the item: the index of the note in the chord (bottom-up), the index of the chord in the measure or voice (left to right), the index of the measures, voices, markers, pitch breakpoints, etc. (all left to right). In case you need to distinguish between chord index and note index, for a given note, you can explicitly use the chordindex or noteindex symbols.
For instance, one could define velocity = duration / 100. + onset * 0.01 or cents = cents + 200, or onset = [cents - 6000] / 100 + 2000 * [voice - 1]. The equation syntax extends in a sense the relative modification syntax; however it is applied to the globality of the selection, and one cannot apply different equations to different notes inside the chord.

method.name: write
method.description:
Syntax: write [<symbol: filename>]
Examples:
• write → save file in native format via dialog box
• write myfile.llll → save bach file in native format
The write message saves all the bach.roll content in native format (with extension .llll). The file name (as symbol) can be given as optional first argument. If no such symbol is given, a dialog box will pop up allowing the choice of the location and file name for saving.
See also:writetxt,exportmidi,read,exportimage

method.name: writetxt
method.description:
Syntax: writetxt [<symbol: filename>] [message attributes]
Examples:
• writetxt → export as a text file, opening a dialog box for the file name
• writetxt myfile.txt → export as a text file with the provided file name
• writetxt myfile.txt @maxdecimals 3 → export with a floating-point precision of 3 decimal digits
• writetxt myfile.txt @maxdecimals 3 @wrap 40 → as the above, limiting the length of each line to 40 characters
• writetxt myfile.txt @maxdepth 1 → no indentation is performed
Message attributes:
@indent (atom, default: tab): Number of spaces for indentation or "tab" symbol
@maxdepth (int, default: -1): Maximum depth for new lines
@wrap (int, default: 0): Maximum number of characters per line (0 means: no wrapping)
The writetxt message saves all the bach.roll content, as llll, in text format (with extension .txt). This will result in a readable text file, but it might also lead to some very slight loss of precision. This is usually negligible, but if it bothers you, use the write message instead.
Text format is easily editable in any text editor, but representation of floating-point numbers is approximate. No limit in size is given for saving a file in text format (differently from what happens while outputting lllls as text in Max). If no file name is provided, a dialog box will open. Furthermore, some message attributes are available, for fine-tuning of the text formatting. Available attributes are:
- maxdecimals (default: 10): the precision for floating-point numbers.
- indent [default: tab]: if set to tab, every sublist that is encountered [up to maxdepth, see below) will be placed on a new line, indented by a number of tabs equal to the depth level of the sublist itself. If set to an integer, the indentation for each depth level will be the corresponding number of spaces.
- maxdepth (default: -1, i.e. no limitation): the maximum depth at which sublists are placed in new lines. If negative, the depth level is counted from the innermost level of each branch of the tree. - wrap (default: 0, i.e. no wrapping): the maximum number of characters to be placed on each line.
- filename (default: not set): the name of the file to be written. If set, this specification overrides the file name set as the first message argument.
See also:write,exportmidi,read,exportimage

attribute.name: accidentalcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of accidentals, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: accidentaldecay
attribute.description: Sets the decay time (in milliseconds) for non-classical accidental display, e.g. for naturalization of altered notes: notes within the said threshold are naturalized, beyond this threshold, the naturalization decays, as if a new measure had started. Leave 0 for "no decay" (accidentals are valid till the end of the roll, as if the whole roll were a single long measure).

attribute.name: accidentalsfont
attribute.description: @description Sets the font used to display accidentals. The official notation bach font is "November for bach", created by Robert Piéchaud (www.poeticprocessing.net) and automatically loaded at bach startup. "November for bach" is a light version of the famous November font. The full November font covers a wide range of music symbols, from Renaissance to the XXI century, and gives a unique, warm and lively look to your music scores. It is fully compatible with Finale, Sibelius and other notation softwares. You can purchase November from this web address: www.klemm-music.de/notation/november/. Other supported fonts are: Accidentals (up to the eighth-tones), Tamburo (up to the quartertones), Maestro, Petrucci, Boulez, Engraver Font Set (up to the semitones).

attribute.name: accidentalsgraphic
attribute.description:
Sets the way of displaying accidentals:
- None: no accidental is displayed.
- Classical: accidentals are displayed with the classical symbols (sharps, flats...). This option is only available if tonedivision is 2, 4 or 8.
- Fraction: accidentals are displayed as fractions of tone (e.g. "-1/4" for quartertone flat or "+1/2" for an ordinary sharp).
- Unreduced Fraction: as the previous one, but fractions are never reduced. For instance, if tonedivision is 48 one would have "+2/8" and not "+1/4". Denominator of each fraction is the tonedivision (thus a tonedivision 2 has denominators 2, as expected for standard sharps and flats).
- Cents: accidentals are displayed as cents differences with respect to the diatonic note. Remark that, unless tonedivision is 100, the displayed cents difference will not in general correspond to the real cents difference: the first one will be indeed a cents difference snapped to the chosen microtonal grid. For instance, if tonedivision is 8, a note having midicents 6027 will be displayed as a middle C with a "+25cents" accidental.

attribute.name: accidentalspreferences
attribute.description:
Sets how non-natural notes should be represented:
- Auto: let bach choose a default representation.
- Sharps: always choose sharp accidentals (more precisely, in general: always choose a representation such that the displayed diatonic pitch is below the actual note).
- Flats: always choose flat accidentals (more precisely, in general: always choose a representation such that the displayed diatonic pitch is above the actual note).
- Custom: use a custom enharmonic table, defined via the enharmonictable attribute.

attribute.name: activepart
attribute.description: Sets the active part number for editing (in case of voice ensembles displaying multiple parts at once, see the part attribute).

attribute.name: additionalstartpad
attribute.description: Sets an additional left pad to the domain display start, in pixels (rescaled according to the vzoom), This pad is located right after each clef, before the music content starts. In bach.roll, this pad is extremely useful if you have chords around 0ms having a lot of accidentals. In this case you can shift, via this pad, the position of the 0ms on the screen, so that all accidentals are correctly displayed. Also see the message adjustadditionalstartpad.

attribute.name: align
attribute.description:
Sets the alignment mode for chords:
- Stems: chords are aligned by their stem (whether or not it is displayed: see the showstems attribute). Two chords falling on the same time instant will have their stems vertically aligned.
- Notehead Center (default): means that chords are aligned by the center of the main notehead. This is similar to what happens in bach.score: two chords falling on the same time instant, one with stem up and one with stem down, will be aligned according to the position of their noteheads, and not the position of their stems. The noteheads will result aligned.
- Notehead End: chords are aligned by the ending point of their noteheads. In this case, the duration line perfectly spans the time duration of the notes.

attribute.name: allowcopypaste
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to copy and paste data via the interface copy/paste commands.

attribute.name: allowglissandi
attribute.description: Toggles the possibility, for duration lines, to have pitch breakpoints, creating glissando-like behaviors. If this is hidden, all breakpoints are not displayed. This defaults to 1.

attribute.name: allowlock
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to lock notation items.

attribute.name: allowmute
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to mute notation items.

attribute.name: allowslothzoom
allowsolo
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to set notation items as "solo".

attribute.name: annotationcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of text annotations, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: annotationfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size for textual annotations over the staff (handled via slot linkage).

attribute.name: annotationsfont
attribute.description: @description Sets the font used to display annotations (default is Arial).

attribute.name: applyslope
attribute.description: Toggle the ability to change the slopes in function slots in order to possibly apply range slopes. The new slopes will hence account for the visual range slope too. By default it is active.

attribute.name: articulationcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of articulations, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: articulationsfont
attribute.description: @description Sets the font used to display articulations. The official notation bach font is "November for bach", created by Robert Piéchaud (www.poeticprocessing.net) and automatically loaded at bach startup. "November for bach" is a light version of the famous November font. The full November font covers a wide range of music symbols, from Renaissance to the XXI century, and gives a unique, warm and lively look to your music scores. It is fully compatible with Finale, Sibelius and other notation softwares. You can purchase November from this web address: www.klemm-music.de/notation/november/. Other supported fonts are: Boulez, Maestro, Petrucci, Engraver Font Set. Not all articulations are supported by all fonts. You can however always define custom articulations with any font of your choice.

attribute.name: autoclear
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to clear the notation object automatically when a new separate syntax information is entered, and a bang is sent through the first inlet. This defaults to 1.

attribute.name: autojump
attribute.digest: Auto Jump To Next Chord While Linear Editing
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to automatically jump to the next chord, while adding or modifying chords in the linear editing system.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Auto Jump To Next Chord While Linear Editing

attribute.name: automessage
attribute.description: Sets a message which is sent automatically to the notation object each time any change happens in the interface (right after the bang is sent through the last outlet). Use this with caution, since it creates a sort of hidden feedback connection!

attribute.name: autosize
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to automatically adapt the number of voices of the notation object depending on the number of voice lllls given as input.

attribute.name: auxstaffcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the auxiliary staves (the ones extending the standard G and F clefs above or below) in RGBA format.

attribute.name: bgcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the background in RGBA format.

attribute.name: bgslotfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size of background slots displayed as text (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: bgslots
attribute.description: Sets the slots to be displayed on the background even when slots windows are not open. The attribute expects a list of integers, each representing a slot number.

attribute.name: bgslottextshift
attribute.description: Sets an horizontal and vertical shift coefficients for the slot text displayed for slots kept in background.

attribute.name: bgslotzoom
attribute.description: Sets the independent zoom factor relative to the slots displayed in background.

attribute.name: bordercolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the border in RGBA format.

attribute.name: breakpointshavenoteheads
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to display pitch breakpoints as real notes (possibly with accidentals). If this is not set, pitch breakpoints are displayed as small diamonds.

attribute.name: breakpointshavevelocity
attribute.description: Toggles the ability, for pitch breakpoints, to have their own independent velocity.

attribute.name: catchplay
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to follow the playhead in the domain during playback.

attribute.name: clefcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of clefs in RGBA format.

attribute.name: clefs
attribute.description:
Sets the clefs. A list of symbols is expected, the length of the list will also automatically change the numvoices attribute and update the number of voices. Each clef symbol can be one of the following: "G", "F", "FG", "FGG", "FFG", "FFGG", "G8va", "G15ma", "G8vb", "G15mb", "F8va", "F15ma", "F8vb", "F15mb", "Soprano", "Mezzo", "Alto", "Tenor", "Soprano", "Mezzo", "Tenor", "Alto", "Barytone", "Percussion", "None".
Clefs such as "FGG" correspond to multiple-staff voices: for instance, in this case, we have a standard piano staff ("FG") with an additional G clef superposed (transposed a 15ma above). The "G8va", "G15ma", "G8vb", "G15mb", "F8va", "F15ma", "F8vb", "F15mb" symbols correspond to octave-transposed clefs. For instance, "G8va" is the G clef, transposed one octave above, whereas "F15mb" is the F clef transposed two octaves below.
A special message clefs auto will detect automatically the most appropriate clefs to display the musical content, and will set them: such message will apply to all the existing voices, and will not change the number of voices. You can use the "auto" symbol instead of any symbol in order to have bach detect automatically the most appropriate clefs for the given voice, depending on its notes (e.g. clefs auto G FG). However, in this case the message will also change the numvoices attribute, as for the standard case. You can restrict the clef to be automatically chosen among a set of clefs by wrapping them between parentheses, preceded by the "auto" symbol. For instance, clefs G F [auto F G] auto will choose the 3rd clef only between F and G, while the fourth clef is chosen among a standard set of predefined clefs.

attribute.name: continuousbang
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to output continuously the bang through the last outlet while the mouse is down and dragging something. Also the automessage, if any, is sent continuously. This defaults to 0.

attribute.name: customspacing
attribute.description:
Toggles the custom spacing mode. If active, this mode will send requests in the form timetopixel ms and pixeltotime pix from the playout, which the user should answer by re-injecting a response respectively in the form pixel pix and time ms in the first inlet. This mechanisms allows the object to paint elements according to the customly specified conversions.
Three modes are available:
None: no custom spacing (default).
Absolute: pixels are considered inside the object box (0 being the leftmost line of the object box). This solution will not automatically account for the scrollbar; this is especially handy if the spacing needs to be retrieved from another notation object, such as a bach.score.
Relative: pixels are considered from the standard 0 position onwards, and the user is not asked to account for the scrollbar.

attribute.name: dblclicksendsvalues
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to individually off-line dump any note or marker by doubleclicking on it. This defaults to 0.

attribute.name: defaultmarkername
attribute.description: Sets the default name for a newly created marker (by default it is "marker"). Although names in bach can be general lllls, the default name must be a simple single symbol. Marker will be then incrementally numbered starting from this default name.

attribute.name: defaultnoteslots
attribute.description: Sets the default slots for a newly created note (in the standard slot syntax). This only applies to notes created via mouse and keyboard.

attribute.name: defaultvelocity
attribute.description: Sets the default velocity for a newly created note. This only applies to notes created via mouse and keyboard.

attribute.name: durationlinewidth
attribute.description: Sets the width of the duration lines (when displayed: see showdurations). In case the showvelocity attribute handles velocities via duration line width, this width is the maximum possible width (corresponding to a velocity of 127), and will be rescaled according to the note (or breakpoint) velocity. Defaults to 2.

attribute.name: dynamicscolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of dynamics, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: dynamicsfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size of dynamics (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: dynamicsvadj
attribute.description: Sets the vertical shift (in pixels, rescaled depending on the vzoom) of the dynamics display. 0 will set the dynamics line coinciding with the bottommost staff line. The default is -20.

attribute.name: embed
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to save the notation object content within the patch. By default this is active.

attribute.name: enhancedstems
attribute.description: Toggle a neater display for stems, but this means at the same time that vertical alignment of synchronous notes might be less precise.

attribute.name: enharmonictable
fadedomain
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to fade the portion of the score at left of the domain, near the clefs, with a transparency gradient (also see highlightdomain).

attribute.name: grid
attribute.description: Toggles the display of the grid.

attribute.name: gridcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the main grid lines ("divisions") in RGBA format.

attribute.name: gridperiodms
attribute.description: Sets the ruler and grid main period ("divisions"), in milliseconds. Defaults to 1000.

attribute.name: hidevoices
attribute.description: Decide which voices must be shown or hidden. A list of 0/1 integers is expected, one for each voice. 0 means that the voice is visibile, 1 means that it is hidden. If less symbols are entered, the other elements are considered to be 1.

attribute.name: highlightdomain
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to highlight the domain with the selectioncolor. This is useful, for instance, in order to align other Max UI objects on the top of bach notation objects.

attribute.name: highlightplay
attribute.description: Toggle the ability to highlight the played notes with the playcolor. By default this is 1.

attribute.name: inset
attribute.description: Sets the stafflines inset at left and right borders of notation object, in pixels (rescaled according to the vzoom). Defaults to 7.

attribute.name: jitmatrix
attribute.description: Sets the name of a jitter matrix to which the canvas should be mirrored

attribute.name: keepselectioniflostfocus
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to keep the current selection when the object lose the focus. This defaults to 1.

attribute.name: keys
attribute.description:
Sets the key signatures. A list of symbols is expected, one symbol for each voice. If less symbols are entered, the last one is padded. The syntax for the single key signature must be an unique symbol (no spaces) with: notename-optional:accidental-optional:mode. Dashes are only set in order to separate parts of the symbol, but must not be included in the symbol.
Note names are allowed both in anglo-saxon (C, D, E...) and in latin (Do, Re, Mi) format. In both ways, they are case insensitive ("c" or "C", "do" or "DO" is the same).
Accidentals are defined as string of ASCII characters, each identifying one accidental. The list of allowed characters is the following one:
"n" = natural
"#" = sharp (+1/2 tone)
"x" = double sharp (+ 1 tone)
"+" = monesis = quarter sharp (+1/4 tone)
"^" = +1/8 tone
"b" = flat (-1/2 tone)
"d" or "-" = mobemol = quarter flat (-1/4 tone)
"v" = -1/8 tone
If no accidental is defined, the natural is used by default.
The mode can be either "M" (major) or "m" minor. If no mode is defined, the major is used by default.

attribute.name: keysigcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the key signature, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: labelfamilies
attribute.description:
Chooses the way in which elements bearing the same names should be visually tagged:
- None (default): don't show label families.
- Singleton: enclose each single notation item in a shape (circle for notes, rectangles for chords and measures) bearing the same color for each family.
- Bounding Box: enclose all items of a certain family in a rectangle bounding box. IMPORTANT: in this case, you might end up with having other notes (not belonging to that family) inside the bounding box.
- Venn: enclose families in an unique closed curve. This will usually work well if points are not too much scattered among other points. Notice that in this case, points not belonging to the label family lie outside the curve. BEW

attribute.name: legend
attribute.description:
Chooses if and where the legend should be displayed: - Never: no legend is ever shown.
- Only For Selection: only selection legend is displayed. Selection legend is located in the upper left corner of the notation object, and is shown whenever a single notation item (e.g. a note) is selected.
- Always: in addition to selection legend, also the mouseover legend is displayed. Mouseover legend is located in the bottom right corner of the notation object, and is shown whenever the mouse moves over the notation object.

attribute.name: legendcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the mouseover legend (displayed at the bottom right corner of the notation object) in RGBA format.

attribute.name: legendfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size of mouseover and selection legends (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: linearedit
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to allow entering in the linear editing mode via Ctrl+clicking (mac) or Shift+Ctrl+clicking (win) on the staff.

attribute.name: lineareditcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color corresponding to linear editing mode, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: linearedittimemultipliers
attribute.description: In linear editing, sets the array of 10 multipliers which will be assigned to keys 1 through 9 plus 0 (meaning 10), and which will be multiplied by the linearedittimestep in order to obtain the duration of a newly created note.

attribute.name: linearedittimestep
attribute.description: In linear editing, sets the base time step in milliseconds (corresponding by default to the duration associated with the key '1' and to the cursor time shifting obtained by using the left/right keyboard arrows).

attribute.name: linkannotationtoslot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is to be displayed as annotation over the staff. 0 (default) means: none.

attribute.name: linkarticulationstoslot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot (of type "articulations") whose content is linked with the articulations display. 0 means: none.

attribute.name: linkdlcolortoslot
attribute.digest: Link Duration Line Color To Slot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is to be associated with the color of the corresponding duration line. An int, float, floatlist or color slot is expected. Int slots are mapped on default colors, float slots are mapped on the color spectrum, floatlist slots are interpreted as RGBA coordinates while color slots are simply taken as they are. 0 (default) means: none.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Link Duration Line Color To Slot

attribute.name: linkdynamicstoslot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is to be displayed as dynamics under the staff. 0 means: none.

attribute.name: linklyricstoslot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is to be displayed as lyrics. A text slot is expected. 0 (default) means: none.

attribute.name: linknotecolortoslot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content must be linked to the note colors. An int, float, floatlist or color slot is expected. Int slots are mapped on default colors, float slots are mapped on the color spectrum, floatlist slots are interpreted as RGBA coordinates while color slots are simply taken as they are. 0 (default) means: none.

attribute.name: linknoteheadadjusttoslot
attribute.digest: Link Note Head Adjust To Slot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is associated with noteheads horizontal and vertical adjustments. An intlist or floatlist slot is expected. 0 (default) means: none.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Link Note Head Adjust To Slot

attribute.name: linknoteheadfonttoslot
attribute.digest: Link Note Head Font To Slot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is the name of the font with which the note should be displayed. A text slot is expected. 0 (default) means: none.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Link Note Head Font To Slot

attribute.name: linknoteheadtoslot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is to be associated with the notehead characters of each note. A slot of type "notehead" (or, for backward compatibility, "int") is expected. 0 means: none.

attribute.name: linknotesizetoslot
attribute.description: Sets the slot number of the slot whose content is linked with a note size factor, as a percentage (100 being the usual size). A float slot is expected (to change both note and accidentals size at the same time), or also a floatlist slot can be used, in which case two factor are expected: one for the note size and one for the accidentals size. 0 (default) means: none.

attribute.name: lockcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of locked items in RGBA format.

attribute.name: loop
attribute.description: Sets the loop region. Two numbers are expected: the starting and ending points of the loop region, in milliseconds. You can substitute to the first number the "start" symbol to have the loop region start from the beginning (equivalent to 0). You can substitute to the second number the "end" symbol to have the loop region last till the end of the bach.roll. You can simply set a loop all to loop the entire bach.roll.

attribute.name: loopcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the loop region in RGBA format.

attribute.name: lyricsalignment
attribute.description: Sets how the lyrics syllables must be aligned with respect to the chord to which they refer. Possibilities are: "Auto", "Left", "Center", "Right". Currently "Auto" completely coincides with "Center", but it might be improved in a future version.

attribute.name: lyricscolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of lyrics in RGBA format.

attribute.name: lyricsfont
attribute.description: @description Sets the font used to display lyrics (default is Arial).

attribute.name: lyricsfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size of lyrics (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: lyricsvadj
attribute.description: Sets the vertical shift (in pixels, rescaled depending on the vzoom) of the lyrics display. 0 will set the lyrics top line coinciding with the bottommost staff line. The default is -16.

attribute.name: markersfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size of marker names (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: maxundosteps
attribute.description: Sets the maximum number of undo steps. 0 means that undo/redo system will be made inactive. The "inf" symbol means unlimited undo steps. Defaults to 50. You should change it to 0 if you perform heavy operations in real-time.

attribute.name: midichannels
attribute.description: Sets the MIDI channels, which are a property of voices: a list with one integer for each voice is expected.

attribute.name: minlength
attribute.description: Sets a minimum length, so that scores having less than the defined length will still be displayed with a scrollbar until the defined minimum length.

attribute.name: mousehover
attribute.description: Toggles mouse hovering capabilities.

attribute.name: mutecolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of muted items in RGBA format.

attribute.name: nonantialiasedstafflines
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to force stafflines to precisely lie on pixels on the screen. If this attribute is 1, the vzoom attribute will be snapped to the closest value allowing stafflines to be drawn precisely on a pixel row. This also means that the staffline-to-staffline distance is an integer (e.g. 4 pixels). If this attribute is 0, all vzoom values are possible, and stafflines will be displayed with any floating-point distance the vzoom will require.

attribute.name: notationfont
attribute.description: @description Sets the font used to display all notation elements except accidentals. The official notation bach font is "November for bach", created by Robert Piéchaud (www.poeticprocessing.net) and automatically loaded at bach startup. "November for bach" is a light version of the famous November font. The full November font covers a wide range of music symbols, from Renaissance to the XXI century, and gives a unique, warm and lively look to your music scores. It is fully compatible with Finale, Sibelius and other notation softwares. You can purchase November from this web address: www.klemm-music.de/notation/november/. Other supported fonts are: Boulez, Maestro, Petrucci, Engraver Font Set.

attribute.name: notecolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of noteheads, duration lines and note tails, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: notifymessages
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to send notifications caused by actions coming from messages, and not only from the interface. For instance, a inscreenpos message will toggle a domain notification, and so on. By default this is inactive.

attribute.name: notifypaint
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to send a notification (in the form of the "painted" symbol) from the playout whenever the object display is refreshed (repainted). Beware: this could be CPU consuming.

attribute.name: numgridsubdivisions
attribute.description: Sets the number of subdivisions for each ruler and grid period. Defaults to 10.

attribute.name: numparts
attribute.description: Sets the part grouping for voices, i.e. the lis. Voices can be assigned to the same staff via this numparts attribute. If multiple voices are assigned to the same staff, this staff is called a "staff ensemble". In this numparts attribute, each integer specifies the number of voices to be displayed on the same staff (or multistaff). For instance, if a score has 4 voices, assigning parts as 1 1 1 1 means that every voice ensemble (displayed staff) has a single voice - or, in other words, that every part is separate voice. If, on the other hand, one assigns 2 2 two staff ensembles are created: voices 1 and 2 are displayed on the same staff (or multistaff), and the same is true for voices 3 and 4. One might even set 4 to show all voices in a single staff or multistaff.

attribute.name: numvoices
attribute.description: Sets the number of voices of the notation object.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: outputpitchesgathered
outputpitchesplayout
outputpitchesseparate
outputslotnames
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to output slot names instead of slot numbers when slot information is sent through the playout.

attribute.name: pitcheditrange
playcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color corresponding to notes being played, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: playheaddragmode
attribute.description: Sets the way the playhead bar responds to mouse clicks. In Relative mode, the playhead keeps its relative position when one clicks - moving the mouse will shift the playhead to higher or lower temporal points in relation to the relative position. In Absolute mode (default), the playhead will automatically jump directly on the clicked location.

attribute.name: playmarkers
attribute.description: Toggle the ability to also send the marker information through the playout during the playback. By default this is 1.

attribute.name: playmode
attribute.description:
Sets the syntax of the content output from the playout: either a chordwise playout syntax, or a notewise playout syntax (default).
For bach.roll, the playout syntax is used whenever the information about a note or chord is sent through the playout (either at playtime or at offline play, or selection dump). The playout syntax is a slight variation of the standard chord gathered syntax. Two different cases apply, according to the playmode attribute value. If the playmode is set to Chordwise, the information about each chord is output in the form
chord voice_number MIDI_channel [onset NOTE1 NOTE2 NOTE3 chord_flag]
where each NOTE is the gathered syntax of the note (see below). If the playmode is set to Notewise, information about each note is output as if the note were the only note in the chord, i.e. in the form
note voice_number MIDI_channel [onset NOTE chord_flag]
where NOTE is the note gathered syntax. The MIDI_channels is the one associated with the voice to which the note or chord belongs. The onset is in milliseconds, The chord_flag is a bitfield summing values of 1 (if chord is locked), 2 (if chord is muted), 4 (if chord is solo).
The playout syntax also concerns markers: they are output in the form: marker NAME_OR_NAMES onset_ms role optional:content where the NAME_OR_NAMES is either a single atom (if the marker has a single name) or a wrapped plain llll containing the names, and the optional:content is only output if the marker role requires it.
In bach.roll, one can assign a role for each marker, so that they can represent elements such as time signatures, tempi, barline, measure divisions. Time signature markers and tempi markers also require a "content", i.e. an llll specifying the time signature or the tempo. When adding a marker via the addmarker message, the role can be specified as third parameter, and the content as fourth parameter. Alternatively, roles and content can be set via the marker inspector. Roles can be:
Time Signature: set by the symbol "timesig", it represents a time signature, and expects the time signature llll as content. For instance, a message to add such a marker could be addmarker 0 foo timesig [4 4].
Tempo: set by the symbol "tempo", it represents a time signature, and expects the tempo llll as content (tempo figure and tempo value). For instance, a message to add such a marker could be addmarker 0 foo tempo [1/8 50], meaning that the tempo is 1/8 = 50.
Measure Barlines: set by the symbol "barline", it represents a barline, and expects no content. For instance, a message to add such a marker could be addmarker 0 foo barline.
Measure Division: set by the symbol "division", it represents a measure division, and expects no content. For instance, a message to add such a marker could be addmarker 0 foo division.
Measure Subdivision: set by the symbol "subdivision", it represents a measure subdivision, and expects no content. For instance, a message to add such a marker could be addmarker 0 foo subdivision.
All these marker can be parsed by bach.quantize in order to automatically retrieve the measureinfo of the entire bach.roll.
For bach.roll, the gathered syntax for any note is, in its simplest form [pitch_cents duration velocity note_flag] where pitch_cents is the pitch of the note in MIDI cents, the duration is measured in milliseconds, the velocity is a value from 1 to 127 corresponding to the note dynamic, and the note_flag is an optional bitfield summing values of 1 (if note is locked), 2 (if note is muted), 4 (if note is solo).
In its most general form, each note can have different specifications and attributes, defining graphics, pitch breakpoints, slots, names. Each of these specifications is done in the form [specification_name SPECIFICATION CONTENT], and must be put after the velocity and before the note_flag. The order in which the specifications are listed is, on the other hand, irrelevant. For instance, a note definition might have the form [7300. 136. 127 [graphic 7400 -1/2] [slots [1 [0. 0. 0.] [0.294118 81.138889 0.] [0.294118 38.805556 0.] [1. 0. 0.]]] [name pippo] 0 ]
Instead of MIDIcents (or cents), one can also instert pitches. The syntax for the single note must be an unique symbol (no spaces) with: notename-optional:accidental-octave_number. Dashes are only set in order to separate parts of the symbol, but must not be included in the symbol.
Names are in anglo-saxon syntax ("C", "D", "E"...), and are case insentitive. Middle C is C5. They and should be immediately followed by the possible accidentals and the octave number, without any space (e.g. D#4).
Accidentals are: # [sharp], b [flat], x [double sharp], q [quartertone sharp], d (quartertone flat), ^ [eighth-tone sharp], v (eighth-tone flat) One can also extend the accidental by setting a rational specification followed by a t. For instance C5+1/16t is middle C, 1/16 tone up.
The graphic specification informs about the enharmonicity status of a note. It is given by an llll in the form [graphic displayed_midicents_ignoring_accidental displayed_accidental], where displayed_midicents_ignoring_accidental are the cents of the diatonic displayed note (ignoring any accidental that it might have), and displayed_accidental is the displayed accidental in rational form (sharp corresponding to 1/2, flat to -1/2, quarterflat to -1/4 and so on). For instance, a Db just above the middle C would have a graphic specification of [graphics 6200 -1/2].
The breakpoint specification informs about possible pitch breakpoints that a note duration line has. This is useful to represent glissandi. It is given by an llll in the form [breakpoints BPT1 BPT2 BPT3...], where each BPT is an llll in the form [relative_x_position delta_midicents slope], where relative_x_position is a double precision number from 0 to 1 representing the point where the breakpoint is, 0 corresponding to the notehead and 1 corresponding to the note tail; delta_midicents is the pitch difference (in midicents) between the breakpoint pitch and the base note pitch; slope is a value from -1 to 1 corresponding to the curvature of the segment of duration line preceding the breakpoint (this implies that the slope of the first breakpoint is always ignored), as for Max curve object (thus 0 being linear).
Two breakpoints are always present: the first breakpoint corresponds always to (0 0 0), and can never be different than this; the last breakpoint corresponds always to the note tail, and must always be in the form [1 delta_midicents slope]. If all breakpoints are trivial (thus if there are just two breakpoints: notehead and tail, and the notetail has delta_midicents = 0), the breakpoint specification is never given as output. For instance, a note making a glissando upwards and then downwards of 200cents, linear while ascending and exponential in the descent, will have the breakpoint specification of the form [breakpoints [0 0 0] [0.5 200 0] [1 0 0.5]].
If the breakpointshavevelocity attribute is set to 1, pitch breakpoints also have velocities, thus the complete BPT specification is in the form (relative_x_position delta_midicents slope velocity), where velocity is a number from 1 to 127 corresponding to the pitch breakpoint dynamic. If different breapoints have different dynamics, the behavior of the velocity between them is considered to be interpolatory, for instance by abstractions like bach.dl2line or bach.dl2curve.
The slots specification informs about the content of each one (or a subset) of the slots of a note. It is given by an llll in the form [slots SLOT1 SLOT2...], where each one of the SLOT is an llll containing the information about one slot, in the form [slot_number SLOT_CONTENT].
The slot content syntax depends on the slot type.
- For slot of type function the content must be in the form: POINT1 POINT2 POINT3... where each POINT is in turn in the form [x y slope], where the first two elements are the coordinates of the point, and the last one is a slope parameter, from -1 to 1, corresponding to the curvature of the segment preceding the point.
- For slot of type int or float the content must be in the simplest form: number.
- For slot of type intlist or floatlist the content must be in the form: number1 number2....
- For slot of type text the content must be in the form: text_as_an_unique_symbol.
- For slot of type llll the content must be in the form: WRAPPED_LLLL, equivalent to [LLLL].
- For slot of type filelist the content must be in the form: filepath1 filepath2 filepath3... active_file_index, where active_file_index is the index of the file which will appear as clicked (active).
- For slot of type spat the content must be in the form: SPATPOINT1 SPATPOINT2 SPATPOINT3... where each SPATPOINT is in turn in the form [t radius angle interpolation_type], where the first element is the time position (by default, if the domain is temporal, this is between 0 and 1), then comes the radius (distance of the sound from the listener) and the angle which the sound makes with respect to a reference vertical direction. Last parameter is an interpolation type, which is 0 (default) for circular spatialization and 1 for linear spatialization.
- For slot of type color the content must be in the form: red green blue alpha, where the parameters are the components of the RGBA color representation (from 0. to 1.).
- For slot of type 3dfunction the content must be in the form: POINT1 POINT2 POINT3... where each POINT is in turn in the form [x y z slope], where the first three elements are the coordinates of the point, and the last one is a slope parameter, from -1 to 1, corresponding to the curvature of the segment preceding the point.
- For slot of type filter, when you need to input content you can use the syntax: filtertype cutoff_frequency_Hz gain_dB Q_or_slope, where filtertype is one of the following symbols: lowpass, highpass, bandpass, bandstop, peaknotch, lowshelf, highshelf, allpass. You can equivalently use for input the syntax a0 a0 a2 b1 b2, where the parameters are the coefficients of a biquad filter, as for biquad~. Finally, when data is output, the syntax is always a combination of the two: a0 a0 a2 b1 b2 [filtertype cutoff_frequency_Hz gain_dB Q_or_slope].
- For slot of type dynfilter the content must be in the form: [t1 FILTER1] [t2 FILTER2] [t3 FILTER3]..., where each FILTER is in the form defined for slot of type filter, just above.
- For slot of type articulations the content must be in the form: art1 art2..., i.e. a sequence of articulations introduced as symbols. The list of the are standard available articulations as symbols is: "staccato" or "stacc", "staccatissimo" or "staccmo", "fermata" or "ferm", "portato" or "por", "accent" or "acc", "accentstaccato" or "accstacc", "accentportato" or "accport", "portatostaccato" or "portstacc", "martellato" or "mart", "martellatostaccato" or "martstacc", "lefthandpizzicato" or "lhpiz", "trill" or "tr", "gruppetto" or "grupp", "upmordent" or "umord", "downmordent" or "dmord", "doublemordent" or "mmord", "upbowing" or "ubow", "downbowing" or "dbow", "tremolo3" or "trem3" (for the tremolo with three slashes), "tremolo2" or "trem2" (for the tremolo with two slashes), "tremolo1" or "trem1" (for the tremolo with a single slash). Notice that the default bach font has all the articulations glyphs; however, not all the other supported fonts do, in particular Boulez doesn't have a certain number of the previous articulations among its glyphs. If you don't see an articulation as you wish (e.g. tremoli with Boulez), it might be because the font doesn't have the proper character, so try to use another font. Articulation symbols can also be retrieved by hovering on the corresponding element in the slot window.
- For slot of type notehead the content must a single notehead symbol. The list of the standard available noteheads as symbols is: "default", "doublewhole", "whole", "white", "black", "diamond", "cross", "plus", "none", "accent", "blacksquare", "whitesquare", "square" "blacktriangle", "whitetriangle", "triangle", "blackrhombus", "whiterhombus", "rhombus". In bach.score, the "square", "triangle" and "rhombus" notehead are black or white depending on the note duration; in bach.roll only the black flavour is used. As for articulations, not all fonts support all symbols. Notehead symbols can also be retrieved by hovering on the corresponding element in the slot window.
- For slot of type togglematrix, intmatrix or floatmatrix the content must be in the form: WRAPPED_MATRIX_AS_LLLL, equivalent to [ROW1 ROW2...], where each row is a wrapped llll. In the bach environment, a matrix is just a llll having depth two, whose first-level sublllls are the rows of the matrix. For instance the matrix [1 0 0] [0 1 0] [0 0 1] is the 3 by 3 identity matrix. A "good" matrix is supposed to be well formed, i.e. all its rows must have the same length. A matrix is square if the length of the rows (which is the number of columns) is the same as the number of rows.
The name specification informs us about a possible name (or possibles names) of a notation item. It is simply given by an llll in the form [name NAME_OR_LLLL_OF_NAMES], where NAME_OR_LLLL_OF_NAMES is either a single of symbols or integer, or an llll corresponding to the name(s) of the notation item. For instance, an item named as "john george" will correspond to the llll [name john george]. An item named "(high 1) (low 2)" will correspond to the llll [name [high 1] [low 2]]. If an element has no names, the name specification is never given as output.

attribute.name: playoutfullpath
attribute.description:
Toggle the ability to output from the playout, instead of the voice number, the full path to get to the played element. The playout syntax normally has as first element the voice number of the output item (note or chord). By default this attribute is 0, and the simple voice number is output as first element.
If this flag is active, for bach.roll, the voice number is substituted with the list [voice_number chord_index], if the playmode is chord-wise, or [voice_number chord_index note_index], if the playmode is note-wise. The chord_index is the index of the chord, when ordered by onsets. The note_index is the index of the note (from the lowest to highest one). For instance, instead of note 1 1 [...] one might have note [1 4 2] 1 [...], meaning that the output information concerns the 2nd note of 4th chord of 1st voice. Voice is anyway always the first element in the output llll.
If this flag is active, for bach.score, the voice number is substituted with a list of lists, namely [LIST1 LIST2...]. The slightly complex form is due to the fact that tied notes or chords are output just once for all from the playout, so that each output element may be a combination of subsequently tied notes or chords. Each one of the LISTs represents one of these elements, and has the form [voice_number measure_number chord_index], if the playmode is chord-wise, or [voice_number measure_number chord_index note_index], if the playmode is note-wise. The chord_index is the index of the chord inside the measure. The note_index is the index of the note (from the lowest to highest one). For instance, instead of note 1 1 [...] one might have note [[1 3 4 2] [1 4 1 3]] 1 [...], meaning that the output information concerns two notes: the 2nd note of 4th chord of 3rd measure of 1st voice, which is tied to the 3rd note of 1st chord of 4th measure of 1st voice. Voice is anyway always the first element in the output llll.

attribute.name: playpartialnotes
attribute.description: Toggle the ability to play partial notes, when the playhead starts from a point where a note has already started but not yet ended. In this case, all temporal information (temporal slots, pitch breakpoints) is properly trimmed, and the corresponding partial note is played. By default this is 1 (quiet playing); if you set the attribute to 2 (verbosely), instead of the onset a llll in the form [partial original_onset played_onset offset] is output.

attribute.name: playpollthrottle
attribute.description: Maximum number of synchronous notation items being output within the same scheduler event. Chords count as singles notation items (so if you have a chord with a large number of notes, this will still count as 1 notation item.

attribute.name: playstep
attribute.description: Approximative step (in milliseconds) for playhead (and notation object) redraw. 0 means that the score is redrawn at each scheduled event. The "approximative" adjective is due to the fact that we need an integer number of ticks between two scheduled events (e.g.: two subsequent chord onsets), so this might slightly vary in each scheduled interval

attribute.name: playwhenlinearediting
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to output chords from the playout, while they are being inserted in the linear editing system.

attribute.name: popupmenuslots
attribute.description: Sets the slots which should show up in the right-click (or two-fingers-tap) popup menu of a note. The attribute expects a list of integers, each representing a slot number.

attribute.name: preventedit
attribute.description:
Prevents the interface editing of the specified elements, specified via an llll. Somehow, this is a lock specified globally for given notation items or features. If the first symbol is a "-" (minus), the editing is prevented for any element or feature, except for the specified ones.
The llll must contain at its root level:
- either single symbols, with the items or features names to be completely "locked", e.g. preventedit measure lyrics inspector will prevent the editing of all measures (one cannot create, delete, modify them), lyrics, and will not allow the opening of the bach inspector;
- or lllls in the form [item_or_feature_name property1 property2 property3...], where properties are symbols which restrict the locking only to a given aspect of the item or feature. For instance, preventedit [measure create delete] [marker onset] will prevent the creation and deletion of measures (but not their modification!), and will also prevent the movement of existing markers (but not the creation of new ones!).
The two approaches.
Here is the complete list of symbols which can be used to define items and feature names; parentheses list symbols for the single properties which one can block for them:
notes (create, delete, onset, duration, pitch, velocity, modify), measures (create, delete, rhythmictree, modify), voice (create, delete, name, clef, key, position, modify), breakpoints (create, delete, onset, pitch, velocity, modify), tempi (create, delete, modify), slots, markers (create, delete, onset, name, modify), articulations (create, delete), selection, zooming, dilationrectangle, groups, inspector, popup, slotinfo, lyrics, cursor, loop, scrollbar, drop.
The "modify" symbol only refers to modification different from the previously defined ones. For instance: preventedit [breakpoints modify] will not prevent the modification of breakpoints onsets, but will, as an example, prevent the modification of breakpoints slopes. Use preventedit [breakpoints onset modify] to do both.

attribute.name: rightclickslot
attribute.digest: Right Click Directly Pops Out Slot
attribute.description: Sets the number of the slot whose window should automatically popup when a right-click (or a two-fingers-tap) is performed on a notehead. 0 (default) means: none (in which case the usual contextual menu pops up).

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Right Click Directly Pops Out Slot

attribute.name: ruler
attribute.description:
Toggles the display of the ruler. Four options are possible:
- Never: ruler is not shown.
- Above: ruler is shown on the upper border of the notation object.
- Below: ruler is shown on the lower border of the notation object.
- Both: ruler is shown on both upper and lower borders of the notation object.

attribute.name: rulercolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the ruler in RGBA format.

attribute.name: rulerlabels
attribute.description: Toggles the display of the ruler labels.

attribute.name: rulerlabelsfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size of ruler labels (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: rulermode
attribute.description: Sets the ruler mode: either a "fixed" mode, where division and subdivisions are fixed independently from the horizontal zoom, or a "smart" mode, where divisions and subdivisions are automatically computed depending on the current level of horizontal zoom.

attribute.name: samplingrate
attribute.description: Sets the currentl sampling rate. "Manually" setting the sampling rate is necessary for a proper handling of the filter slots. No object in the bach library is a DSP objects, so this information should be set "by hand" (it could easily come from dspstatus~).

attribute.name: scrollbarcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the scrollbars in RGBA format.

attribute.name: selectedlegendcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the selection legend (displayed at the top left corner of the notation object, when one clicks on a notation item) in RGBA format.

attribute.name: selectioncolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of each selected notehead, accidental, duration line and note tail in RGBA format.

attribute.name: senddoneafterpaint
attribute.description: If this is 1, the done notification is not sent when the content has been loaded or built, but after the content has been painted (which, in general, is later: paint is done at low priority). This is handy if you need to retrieve appearance data (such as pixel position) which is computed inside the paint method, and not when the object is loaded. If this is 0, on the other hand, the notification is sent right after the content has been loaded or built, and you have no guarantee that the display data will be correct when the notification is sent. By default this is 1.

attribute.name: senddoneatstartup
attribute.digest: Send 'Done' At Startup (If Data Was Saved)
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to send a done notification through the playout (or the notification outlet for bach.slot) at the object instantiation, if content saved with the object is loaded.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Send 'Done' At Startup (If Data Was Saved)

attribute.name: showaccidentalspreferences
attribute.description:
Handles the display of accidentals:
- Classically (default): for bach.score: accidentals are displayed classically, i.e. on the first (altered) note requiring them, and them never for any other note inside the same measure (but cautionary accidentals are possible: see the attribute cautionaryaccidentals); for bach.roll: this coincides with Altered Note (No Naturals) (see below).
- Always: accidentals are always displayed for all altered and naturals notes.
- Altered Notes: accidentals are always displayed for any altered note. Natural signs are preserved for notes which have to cancel such accidental.
- Altered Notes (No Repetition): accidentals are always displayed for any altered note, but dropped for immediate repetitions of the same note.
- Altered Note (No Naturals): accidentals are always displayed for any altered note, and natural signs are dropped for notes having to cancel such accidentals. In this case all non-natural notes have their accidental, and all natural notes have no accidental.
- Never: accidentals are never shown (always hidden).
IMPORTANT: be aware of the fact that, due to the cross dependencies between accidentals, in bach.roll the "Altered Notes" "Altered Notes (No Repetition)" configurations can be sensibly slower than any other any other configuration (bach.score, on the other hand, does not suffer from this issue).

attribute.name: showannotations
attribute.description: Toggles the display of annotations. Annotations are handled via slot linkage: pick a text slot and link it with "annotation".

attribute.name: showarticulations
attribute.description: Toggles the display of articulations. Articulations are handled via slot linkage: pick an articulations slot and link it with "articulations".

attribute.name: showarticulationsextensions
attribute.description: Toggles the display of articulation extensions (such as trill lines).

attribute.name: showborder
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to display the object border.

attribute.name: showdurations
attribute.description: Toggles the display of the duration lines.

attribute.name: showdynamics
attribute.description: Toggles the display of dynamics.

attribute.name: showfocus
attribute.description: Toggles the display of a thicker border when the notation object has the focus.

attribute.name: showgroups
attribute.description:
Chooses how the chord grouping should be displayed:
- None: groups are not displayed in any way.
- Lines: groups are displayed by linking chord stems with dashed lines.
- Colors: groups are displayed by assigning to each group a particular color.
- Lines And Colors (default): both of the two previous devices are adopted.

attribute.name: showhairpins
attribute.description: Toggles the display of hairpins for dynamics.

attribute.name: showledgerlines
attribute.description:
Chooses how to display the ledger lines:
- Never: ledger lines are always hidden.
- Standard: the only displayed ledger lines are the one really needed to understand note positioning (i.e. ledger lines between main and auxiliary staves are hidden if not needed).
- Always Refer To Main Staves: always show all ledger lines, even between main and auxiliary staves.

attribute.name: showlockcolor
attribute.description:
Chooses when the locked elements should be displayed with the color associated with the element locking (see the lockcolor attribute):
- Never: never use the lockcolor.
- When Selecteed: use the lockcolor only when elements are selected, instead of the selectioncolor.
- When Not Selected: use the lockcolor only when elements are not selected.
- Always: always use the lockcolor.

attribute.name: showloop
attribute.description: Toggles the display of the loop region.

attribute.name: showlyrics
attribute.description: Toggles the display of lyrics.

attribute.name: showmarkers
attribute.description: Toggles the display of markers.

attribute.name: showmutecolor
attribute.description:
Chooses when the muted elements should be displayed with the color associated with the element muting (see the mutecolor attribute):
- Never: never use the mutecolor.
- When Selecteed: use the mutecolor only when elements are selected, instead of the selectioncolor.
- When Not Selected: use the mutecolor only when elements are not selected.
- Always: always use the mutecolor.

attribute.name: shownotenames
attribute.digest: Show Note Names In Selection Legend
attribute.description: Toggles the display of note names in the selection legend

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Show Note Names In Selection Legend

attribute.name: showpartcolors
attribute.description: Toggles the display of different voice parts (see the parts attribute) with different colors.

attribute.name: showplayhead
attribute.description: Toggles the constant display of the playhead line (even while not playing).

attribute.name: showscrollbar
attribute.description: Toggles the display of the horizontal scrollbar, if needed. If unneeded, the scrollbar is not shown. By default this is 1: you should set it to 0 only if you want to always hide the horizontal scrollbar.

attribute.name: showslotlabels
attribute.description: Toggles the display of automatic labels for points in the function slots and for bars in the intlist or floatlist slots.

attribute.name: showslotlegend
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to display the slot legend at the top right angle.

attribute.name: showslotnumbers
attribute.digest: Show Slot Numbers In Slot Window
attribute.description: Toggles the display of slot numbers in the slot windows.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Show Slot Numbers In Slot Window

attribute.name: showsolocolor
attribute.description:
Chooses when the elements set as "solo" should be displayed with the color associated with the solo elements (see the solocolor attribute):
- Never: never use the solocolor.
- When Selecteed: use the solocolor only when elements are selected, instead of the selectioncolor.
- When Not Selected: use the solocolor only when elements are not selected.
- Always: always use the solocolor.

attribute.name: showstems
attribute.description: Toggles the display of the chord stems. Values are: 0 = don't show, 1 = show main stem, 2 = show both main and auxiliary unison stems (default).

attribute.name: showtails
attribute.description: Toggles the display to display the note tails (this only works if showdurations is active.

attribute.name: showvelocity
attribute.description:
Chooses the way in which velocities should be displayed:
- None (default): velocities are simply not displayed in any way.
- Colorscale: velocities are mapped on a color scale ranging from almost white (velocity = 1) to the ordinary notecolor (velocity 127).
- Colorspectrum: velocities are mapped on a spectrum of colors ranging from red (velocity = 1) to blue (velocity = 127).
- Alpha: velocities are mapped on a the transparency (alpha) channel, from 0 (velocity = 1, fully transparent) to 1 (velocity = 127, fully opaque).
- Duration Line Width: velocities are mapped on the width of the duration line, from almost 0 (velocity = 1, extremely thin) to the width defined via the attribute durationlinewidth (velocity = 127, maximum thickness).
- Notehead Size: velocities are mapped on the size of the notehead and accidentals, from the smallest size (velocity = 1) to the ordinary size (velocity = 127).

attribute.name: showvoicenames
attribute.description: Toggles the display of voice names.

attribute.name: showvscrollbar
attribute.description: Toggles the display of the vertical scrollbar, if needed. If unneeded, the scrollbar is not shown. By default this is 1: you should set it to 0 only if you want to always hide the vertical scrollbar.

attribute.name: slotfunctionptradius
attribute.description: Sets the size of the radius of breakpoints inside slots of type function (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: slotminimumwindowwidth
attribute.description: Sets the minimum width of a slot window.

attribute.name: slotwinalpha
attribute.description: Sets the percentage of transparency of the slot windows (0 being completely transparent, 100 being completely opaque.

attribute.name: slotwinzoom
attribute.description: Sets an independent zoom factor for slot windows. This factor is set as a percentage, 100 corresponding to the default standard zoom.

attribute.name: smartmarkernames
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to display the marker names on multiple lines to avoid collisions.

attribute.name: snaplinearedit
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to automatically snap linear editing to the displayed grid (if any). By default this is on.

attribute.name: snapmarkers
attribute.digest: Snap Markers To Grid When Editing
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to automatically snap the markers to the displayed grid (if any). By default this is off. When it is on, one can press the Ctrl key (mac) or Shift+Ctrl key (win) before releasing the mouse button in order to prevent snapping.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Snap Markers To Grid When Editing

attribute.name: snaponset
attribute.digest: Snap Onset To Grid When Editing
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to automatically snap the onset of the edited chords and notes to the displayed grid (if any). By default this is off. When it is on, one can press the Ctrl key (mac) or Shift+Ctrl key (win) before releasing the mouse button in order to prevent snapping.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Snap Onset To Grid When Editing

attribute.name: snappitch
attribute.digest: Snap Pitch To Grid When Editing
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to precisely snap the midicents of each edited note to the current microtonal grid. If this is active, not only the display but also the midicent values of the edited notes can only be one of the elements of the chosen temperament (see the tonedivision to know more about microtonal grids and temperaments). By default this is active.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Snap Pitch To Grid When Editing

attribute.name: snaptail
attribute.digest: Snap Tail To Grid When Editing
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to automatically snap the tails of the edited chords and notes to the displayed grid (if any). By default this is off. When it is on, one can press the Ctrl key (mac) or Shift+Ctrl key (win) before releasing the mouse button in order to prevent snapping.

attribute.name: label
attribute.value: Snap Tail To Grid When Editing

attribute.name: solocolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of items set as "solo" in RGBA format.

attribute.name: spacebarplay
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to sequence events via the spacebar (see keyboard commands).

attribute.name: staffcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the main staves (the ones always carring the clefs) in RGBA format.

attribute.name: stafflines
attribute.description: Sets the staff lines. An llll containing as many elements as the number of voices is expected, if less elements are input, the last one is padded. Each staff line element (for the given voice) can be either an integer number, representing the number of stafflines the voice will have (e.g. 3, meaning: just 3 stafflines, located around the middle line of a standard 5-lines-staff), or an llll, containing the explicit indices of the lines to be displayed. In this case, 1 correspond to the bottommost staffline of the standard 5-lines-staff, 5 to the topmost one, and all other numbers work accordingly. Zero or negative indices are also allowed. For instance, [0 5 6] will set as stafflines the one below the bottommost default one, the topmost line of a default staff, and the one above. Use 0 or nil or [] to hide all the stafflines of a staff.

attribute.name: stemcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of chord stems, in RGBA format.

attribute.name: subdivisiongridcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the each grid subdivision line in RGBA format.

attribute.name: thinannotations
thinannotationsclearsym
attribute.description: If thinannotations is set to 2 (Remove With Clearing Symbol), this attribute sets the clearing symbol to remove the annotation label.

attribute.name: tonedivision
attribute.description: In the bach environment, the tone division defines the microtonal accuracy of the symbolic representation, by representing the number of steps in which each tone is divided. For the standard semitonal representation (where just sharps and flats suffice), one can stick with tonedivision being 2, meaning: the tone is divided into two semitones. By increasing this value, the microtonal grid gets more dense: for instance, 4 is the quartertonal grid (where each tone is divided in 4 quartertones); 8 is the eight-tonal grid, and so on.

attribute.name: undobang
attribute.description: Toggles the ability of send the bang through the rightmost outlet when an undo/redo action is performed.

attribute.name: useloop
verboseundo
attribute.description: Toggles the ability of undo system to post the performed undo or redo steps in the Max window. By default this is inactive.

attribute.name: voicenames
attribute.description: Sets the voice names. An llll containing as many elements as the number of voices is expected, if less elements are input, the last one is padded. Each voice name can be either a single symbol, or a wrapped llll, for multiple naming (if you want to assign more than one name to the same voice). Use the [] or nil list to skip the naming for a voice. For instance: voicenames Foo [John Ringo] [] "Electric Piano" sets "Foo" as name for the first voice, sets both "John" and "Ringo" as names for the second one, leaves the third voice without name, and sets "Electric Piano" (as a single symbol) as name for the fourth voice.

attribute.name: voicenamesalign
attribute.description: Sets the alignment for the voice names, at the beginning of the staff, with respect to all other voice names. Possibilities are: "Left", "Center", "Right".

attribute.name: voicenamesfontsize
attribute.description: Sets the font size of voice names (rescaled according to the vzoom).

attribute.name: voicespacing
attribute.description: Sets the spaces between voices. A list of floating numbers is expected, one more than the number of voices. Indeed the first number will correspond to the blank space above the first voice, the second one to the space between the first and second voice, and so on, till the last one which will correspond to the space below the last voice. Numbers are pixel distances (rescaled with respect to the vzoom attribute).

attribute.name: vzoom
attribute.description: Sets the vertical zoom percentage (auto being the default value). This factor is actually a global zoom factor, according to which every displayed element is rescaled. This means, for instance that the distance between elements (and not only the size of elements) changes as this vzoom is changed. A fixed value such as 100 will keep the global zoom fixed as the object vertical size changes. Use the auto symbol to link the vertical zoom to the object box height. In this case you can retrieve the vertical zoom via getvzoom.

attribute.name: zoom
attribute.description: Sets the horizontal zoom percentage (100 being the default value).

entry.name: Outlet 1 (llll)
entry.description: Whole object dump. The gathered syntax of the whole bach.roll (or a part of it, depending on the dump message arguments) is sent through this outlet. See the dump message to know more about the output syntax.

entry.name: Outlet 2 (llll)
entry.description:
Onsets. The onsets (in milliseconds) in separate syntax. The separate synax of a given parameter is nothing but an llll containing the value of such parameter for each notation item to which it can be applied. The llll should be properly structured depending on the hierarchical structure.
In bach.roll, onsets are the only parameter assigned chordwise (they are a propriety of chords, rather than notes). The separate syntax for onsets will be thus structured as: an llll for each voice, containing a value for each chord. For instance: [0 1000 2000 3000] [100 400] [250 2500].
Cents, durations, velocities and extras are all assigned notewise in bach.roll (they are propriety of notes, rather than chords). The separate syntax for any of such parameters will be thus structured as: an llll for each voice, containing an llll for each chord, containing a value for each note. For instance, a cents assignment can have the following form: [[6000] [6000 6400] [6200] [6200 6500]] [[7200] [6500 7200 7500]] [[5500] [5400]].
While using separate syntax as input, for all notewise parameter, except for extras, a shortcut is tolerated: one can assign a single value for each chord (and not each note) meaning that such value must be applied to the whole chord. If no chord exists, and such value must create a chord, then a chord with a single note si created. For instance, bach.roll can properly understand [6000 [6000 6400] 6200 [6200 6500]] [[7200] [6500 7200 7500]] [5500 5400]. However, when the separate syntax is retrieven as output, the llll will be always properly shaped, according to the musical hierarchy, without any shortcut.
